pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 207, 279, 221]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 248, 560, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 313, 386, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 343, 235, 356]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 357, 504, 371]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 372, 890, 400]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 382, 414]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 429, 890, 458]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 458, 890, 473]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 488, 555, 503]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 517, 764, 530]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 532, 416, 546]]<|/det|>
Any working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 547, 359, 561]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 324, 90]]<|/det|>
What is a unit for stress?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 100, 690, 119]]<|/det|>
A \(\mathsf{kgm}^{- 1}\mathsf{s}^{- 2}\) B \(\mathsf{kgm}^{- 2}\mathsf{s}^{- 2}\) C \(\mathsf{Nm}^{- 1}\) D \(\mathsf{Nm}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 146, 96, 165]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 146, 605, 163]]<|/det|>
Physical quantities can be classed as vectors or as scalars.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 177, 515, 193]]<|/det|>
Which pair of quantities consists of two vectors?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 205, 353, 221]]<|/det|>
A kinetic energy and force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 231, 325, 247]]<|/det|>
B momentum and time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 257, 428, 273]]<|/det|>
C velocity and electric field strength

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 283, 350, 299]]<|/det|>
D weight and temperature

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 327, 96, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 327, 551, 345]]<|/det|>
Two dogs pull a sledge along an icy track, as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 355, 820, 628]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 641, 919, 674]]<|/det|>
Dog X pulls with a force of 200N at an angle of \(65^{\circ}\) to the front edge of the sledge. Dog Y pulls with a force of 120N at an angle of \(45^{\circ}\) to the front edge of the sledge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 687, 730, 704]]<|/det|>
What is the resultant forward force on the sledge exerted by the two dogs?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 715, 703, 732]]<|/det|>
A 80N B 170N C 270N D 320N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
In the circuit shown, an analogue ammeter is to be recalibrated as a thermometer. The ammeter is connected in series with a thermistor. The thermistor is a component with a resistance that varies with temperature. The graph shows how the resistance \(R\) of the thermistor changes with temperature \(T\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 146, 797, 303]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 318, 705, 335]]<|/det|>
Which diagram could represent the temperature scale on the ammeter?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[75, 346, 922, 515]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 539, 94, 558]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 539, 513, 556]]<|/det|>
The sides of a cube are measured with calipers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 570, 556, 587]]<|/det|>
The measured length of each side is \((30.0 \pm 0.1) \text{mm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 600, 652, 617]]<|/det|>
The measurements are used to calculate the volume of the cube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 630, 720, 647]]<|/det|>
What is the percentage uncertainty in the calculated value of the volume?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 658, 685, 675]]<|/det|>
A \(0.01\%\) B \(0.3\%\) C \(1\%\) D \(3\%\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 607, 90]]<|/det|>
A tennis ball falls freely, in air, from the top of a tall building.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 749, 120]]<|/det|>
Which graph best represents the variation with time \(t\) of the distance \(s\) fallen?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 131, 814, 513]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 541, 94, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 541, 833, 559]]<|/det|>
The graph shows the variation with mass of the weight of objects on a particular planet.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 571, 680, 758]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 770, 628, 788]]<|/det|>
What is the value of the acceleration of free fall on the planet?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 798, 728, 816]]<|/det|>
**A** \(0.63 \text{m s}^{-2}\) **B** \(1.6 \text{m s}^{-2}\) **C** \(3.2 \text{m s}^{-2}\) **D** \(9.8 \text{m s}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 603, 90]]<|/det|>
The momentum of a car of mass \(m\) increases from \(p_{1}\) to \(p_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 551, 120]]<|/det|>
What is the increase in the kinetic energy of the car?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 136, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 125, 715, 158]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{(p_2^2 - p_1^2)}{2m} \qquad \text{B} \qquad \frac{(p_2 - p_1)^2}{2m} \qquad \text{C} \qquad \frac{p_2 - p_1}{2m} \qquad \text{D} \qquad \frac{p_1 - p_2}{2m}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 189, 94, 207]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 189, 918, 206]]<|/det|>
Two similar spheres, each of mass \(m\) and travelling with speed \(v\), are moving towards each other.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 218, 640, 312]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 322, 497, 339]]<|/det|>
The spheres have a head-on elastic collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 352, 349, 368]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 381, 140, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 381, 463, 397]]<|/det|>
The spheres stick together on impact.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 407, 140, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 407, 510, 424]]<|/det|>
The total kinetic energy after impact is \(mv^2\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 434, 141, 452]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 434, 528, 450]]<|/det|>
The total kinetic energy before impact is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 460, 504, 476]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 459, 504, 475]]<|/det|>
The total momentum before impact is \(2mv\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 504, 107, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 504, 920, 536]]<|/det|>
A horizontal metal bar PQ of length 50.0 cm is hinged at end P. The diagram shows the metal bar viewed from above.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 546, 720, 692]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 706, 920, 739]]<|/det|>
Two forces of 16.0N and 5.0N are in the horizontal plane and act on end Q as shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 752, 582, 768]]<|/det|>
What is the total moment about P due to the two forces?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 780, 717, 796]]<|/det|>
<pre>A 1.5N m B 4.4N m C 6.5N m D 9.4N m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
Blocks P, Q, R and S are made from material of the same density. Block T is made from a material of twice the density of the material of the other blocks.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 685, 135]]<|/det|>
The cross-sectional area and height of each of the blocks are shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[102, 142, 895, 324]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 336, 598, 354]]<|/det|>
Which two blocks exert the same pressure on the ground?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 364, 722, 382]]<|/det|>
A P and T B Q and R C Q and S D S and T

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 410, 107, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 409, 670, 427]]<|/det|>
Two parallel forces, each of magnitude \(F\) , act on a rod of length \(5d\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 439, 919, 472]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows the positions of the two forces that will produce the largest torque on the rod?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 482, 880, 764]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|> Liquids X and Y are stored in large open tanks. Liquid X has a density of \(800 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\) and liquid Y has a density of \(1200 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 460, 135]]<|/det|> At which depths are the pressures equal? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 147, 434, 291]]<|/det|>
depth in liquid X/mdepth in liquid Y/m
A820
B1015
C1510
D208
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 320, 107, 339]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 919, 354]]<|/det|> A train of mass \(3.3 \times 10^{6} \text{kg}\) is moving at a constant speed up a slope inclined at an angle of \(0.64^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The engine of the train is producing a useful output power of \(14 \text{MW}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 365, 726, 383]]<|/det|> Assume that there are no frictional forces opposing the motion of the train. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 396, 372, 413]]<|/det|> What is the speed of the train? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 424, 732, 441]]<|/det|> A \(0.43 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\) B \(4.2 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\) C \(39 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\) D \(380 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 470, 109, 488]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 470, 920, 502]]<|/det|> A cannon-ball of mass \(3.50 \text{kg}\) is fired at a speed of \(22.0 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\) from a gun on a ship at a height of \(6.00 \text{m}\) above sea level. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 515, 919, 547]]<|/det|> The total energy of the cannon-ball is the sum of the gravitational potential energy relative to the surface of the sea and the kinetic energy. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 560, 641, 577]]<|/det|> What is the total energy of the cannon-ball as it leaves the gun? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 588, 710, 605]]<|/det|> A 206J B 641J C 847J D 1050J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 634, 107, 651]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 634, 919, 666]]<|/det|> An aircraft travels at a constant velocity of \(90 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\) in horizontal flight. The diagram shows some of the forces acting on the aircraft. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 675, 749, 772]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 787, 406, 804]]<|/det|> The mass of the aircraft is \(2000 \text{kg}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 816, 515, 834]]<|/det|> What is the power produced by the thrust force? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 845, 752, 863]]<|/det|> A \(1.8 \times 10^{5} \text{W}\) B \(2.2 \times 10^{5} \text{W}\) C \(1.8 \times 10^{6} \text{W}\) D \(2.0 \times 10^{6} \text{W}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 75, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 920, 107]]<|/det|>

The wave can be represented on a graph showing the variation of the displacement of the particles with distance from the source.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 416, 918, 433]]<|/det|>
What can be deduced from a table of wavelengths of the waves in the electromagnetic spectrum?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 560, 461]]<|/det|>
A Green light has a shorter wavelength than X-rays.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 471, 578, 488]]<|/det|>
B Red light has a shorter wavelength than green light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 497, 765, 514]]<|/det|>
C The wavelength range for radio waves is less than that for infra-red waves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 523, 693, 540]]<|/det|>
D The wavelength range for X-rays is less than that for radio waves.

Light from one of the stars is observed on the Earth. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[343, 114, 650, 208]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 221, 919, 253]]<|/det|> The observed frequency of the light varies between a minimum frequency \(f_{\mathrm{min}}\) and a maximum frequency \(f_{\mathrm{max}}\), as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 263, 682, 389]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 403, 509, 420]]<|/det|> The rate of rotation of the binary star increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 433, 524, 450]]<|/det|> What is the change to \(f_{\mathrm{max}}\) and the change to \(f_{\mathrm{min}}\)? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 462, 407, 590]]<|/det|>
\(f_{\mathrm{max}}\)\(f_{\mathrm{min}}\)
Adecreasesdecreases
Bdecreasesincreases

Dincreasesincreases

A teacher sets up the apparatus shown to demonstrate a double-slit interference pattern on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 308, 644, 325]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 388, 366, 404]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 414, 468, 430]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 710, 484, 726]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
A pipe, closed at one end, has a loudspeaker at the open end. A stationary sound wave is formed in the air within the pipe with an antinode at the open end of the pipe.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 115, 728, 173]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 189, 382, 206]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 219, 432, 236]]<|/det|>
The speed of sound in air is \(340 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 249, 832, 266]]<|/det|>
Which frequency of sound from the loudspeaker would **not** produce a stationary wave?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 278, 714, 295]]<|/det|>
**A** \(100 \text{Hz}\) **B** \(200 \text{Hz}\) **C** \(300 \text{Hz}\) **D** \(500 \text{Hz}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 323, 920, 356]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 397, 337, 415]]<|/det|>
**A** \(0.20 \text{V m}^{-1}\) downwards

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 424, 313, 441]]<|/det|>
**B** \(0.20 \text{V m}^{-1}\) upwards

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 450, 325, 467]]<|/det|>
**C** \(5.0 \text{V m}^{-1}\) downwards

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 476, 303, 493]]<|/det|>
**D** \(5.0 \text{V m}^{-1}\) upwards

<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 521, 920, 553]]<|/det|>
A charged particle is in the electric field between two horizontal metal plates connected to a battery, as shown. There is a force \(F\) on the particle due to the electric field.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 562, 715, 666]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 680, 444, 697]]<|/det|>
The separation of the plates is doubled.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 710, 430, 727]]<|/det|>
What is the new force on the particle?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 738, 133, 763]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 738, 680, 765]]<|/det|>
\(F\) **B** \(\frac{F}{2}\) **C** \(F\) **D** \(2F\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 633, 90]]<|/det|>
The current \(I\) in a metal wire is given by the expression shown.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 103, 539, 120]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 134, 413, 151]]<|/det|>
What does the symbol \(n\) represent?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 140, 180]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 163, 560, 180]]<|/det|>
the number of atoms per unit volume of the metal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 190, 567, 206]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 187, 567, 204]]<|/det|>
the number of free electrons per atom in the metal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 215, 140, 233]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 215, 621, 231]]<|/det|>
the number of free electrons per unit volume of the metal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 241, 625, 257]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 240, 625, 256]]<|/det|>
the total number of electrons per unit volume of the metal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 285, 107, 303]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 285, 919, 318]]<|/det|>
The circuit diagrams show two lamps X and Y each connected to a cell. The current in lamp X is \(0.50\mathsf{A}\) and its resistance is \(9.6\mathsf{\Omega}\) . The current in lamp Y is \(3.0\mathsf{A}\) and its resistance is \(1.2\mathsf{\Omega}\) .

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 330, 745, 452]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 470, 410, 503]]<|/det|>
What is the ratio \(\frac{\text{power in lamp } \mathsf{X}}{\text{power in lamp } \mathsf{Y}}?\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 683, 527]]<|/det|>
<pre>A 0.22 B 0.75 C 1.3 D 4.5

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 558, 107, 575]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 558, 919, 590]]<|/det|>
A cylindrical piece of a soft, electrically-conducting material has resistance \(R\) . It is rolled out so that its length is doubled but its volume stays constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 603, 346, 618]]<|/det|>
What is its new resistance?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 625, 683, 656]]<|/det|>
<pre>A \(\frac{R}{2}\) B \(R\) C \(2R\) D \(4R\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 686, 107, 704]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 686, 920, 718]]<|/det|>
The sum of the electrical currents into a point in a circuit is equal to the sum of the currents out of the point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 732, 350, 747]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 759, 756, 776]]<|/det|>
<pre>A This is Kirchhoff's first law, which results from the conservation of charge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 785, 756, 802]]<|/det|>
<pre>B This is Kirchhoff's first law, which results from the conservation of energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 812, 784, 828]]<|/det|>
<pre>C This is Kirchhoff's second law, which results from the conservation of charge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 838, 784, 854]]<|/det|>
<pre>D This is Kirchhoff's second law, which results from the conservation of energy.

Another cell M is connected in series with resistors of resistances \(5.00 \Omega\), \(10.0 \Omega\) and \(15.0 \Omega\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[228, 117, 768, 375]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 390, 920, 422]]<|/det|> The potential difference (p.d.) between P and Q is balanced against \(12.5 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire, so that the ammeter reads zero. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 435, 902, 451]]<|/det|> The p.d. across the other resistors is then balanced against other lengths of the resistance wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 465, 920, 497]]<|/det|> Which balanced lengths of resistance wire correspond to the connection points given in the table? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 510, 570, 636]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A motor is required to operate at a distance of \(800 \text{m}\) from its power supply. The motor requires a potential difference (p.d.) of \(16.0 \text{V}\) and a current of \(0.60 \text{A}\) to operate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 607, 135]]<|/det|>
Two wires are used to supply power to the motor as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 147, 714, 235]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 252, 613, 269]]<|/det|>
The resistance of each of these wires is \(0.0050 \Omega\) per metre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 282, 562, 299]]<|/det|>
What is the minimum output p.d. of the power supply?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 311, 710, 328]]<|/det|>
A 11.2V B 16.0V C 18.4V D 20.8V

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 356, 107, 374]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 356, 433, 373]]<|/det|>
Which elementary particle is a lepton?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 386, 210, 400]]<|/det|>
A proton

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 412, 222, 425]]<|/det|>
B neutron

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 438, 222, 451]]<|/det|>
C electron

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 463, 203, 477]]<|/det|>
D quark

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 510, 107, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 510, 620, 527]]<|/det|>
How many down quarks are in a nucleus of hydrogen-3, \(^3_1H?\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 540, 667, 555]]<|/det|>
A 2 B 3 C 4 D 5

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 585, 107, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 585, 465, 602]]<|/det|>
What is the correct equation for \(\beta^{+}\) decay?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 615, 607, 631]]<|/det|>
A neutron \(\rightarrow\) proton + electron + electron antineutrino

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 643, 577, 658]]<|/det|>
B neutron \(\rightarrow\) proton + electron + electron neutrino

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 670, 607, 686]]<|/det|>
C proton \(\rightarrow\) neutron + positron + electron antineutrino

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 698, 577, 713]]<|/det|>
D proton \(\rightarrow\) neutron + positron + electron neutrino

This is produced for each series of examinations and is freely available to download at www.cie.org.uk after the live examination series.
